Author: npk
Content: Yes, I 'm not sure if any of these 10 mashes satisfies my criteria for awesome.

Author: jaggederest
Content:
Well, it's very simple: digg has two options, either fight, or shut down.

They've empowered their users, and their users have informed them in no uncertain terms that they will not accept censorship.

That doesn't mean that they have to fight, merely that if they want their community to remain largely as it is, they cannot censor. As the saying goes, they can't "have their cake and eat it too"

Author: immad
Content:
I am told deviantart.com does a reasonably good job in combining a community with digital art. I have never investigated it in depth, might do vector graphics too.

Seems like a completely different proposition to flickr since everyone can take photos but far fewer people do vector graphics. Perhaps there is an opportunity there, I dont know that much about the space.

Author: npk
Content:
Wow, China's got $1.3T in the bank, just waiting to be invested. With that much mass, you've got to reckon there's a startup out there that could make serious money from China's investment wake. Anyone who can figure out the Chinese investment strategy is going to make serious bank.

Author: Goladus
Content:
I'd agree, if the article was about how the board tried to stimulate a cult of quality within the company, and despite their best efforts they simply weren't able to salvage anything from the software.

In spite of the software issues, they had a head start in terms of popularity and users.

Author: danielha
Content: I don't know much about publishing, but I would think each department has a copy of their respective contributions. If I liken their editorial system to version control, why wouldn't, say, the art department have layouts on their local machines?
